I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to build a PID controller with and arduino.
Control systems, basic robotics concepts, circuit wiring and controlling a motor with Arduino!
I learned a lot about motor control, block diagrams, and feedback systems.

Besides the basic electronics background developed in EENG 200, we gained many new skills. This was the first time I coded in Arduino or used Arduino hardware. Further, I was introduced to concepts of control strategies and feedback systems on an interesting and exciting platform.
Learned a lot about feedback control systems, laplace transforms, and circuits.
I learnt a lot about mechatronics from a mechanical perspective, which I really enjoyed!
This was one of my favorite classes I have taken so far at Yale. The material is super interesting and you get a lot of hands on experience with Arduinos.
From 0 to being able to make a robot.

In taking this course, I gained a much better sense of how to build controllers and control systems, using motors, the Arduino, and other peripheral components. This course did a great job in outlining both the theory and the practice of control systems, through lecture and the labs, respectively.
Insight into the cross between mechanical, electrical and software systems and how they can be confimed to form a fully functioning mechatronic system.

This class chiefly provides experience with Arduino and utilizing electronic components to accomplish mechanical things (motors, sensors). We also get an introduction to systems theory as well as systems control but without explicitly focusing on this for the whole semester it is hard to grasp onto
A good combination of mechanical and electrical
Basics of control systems, lots of arduino stuff, healthy dose of circuits, little bit of matlab, some assembly code, and recap of the harder stuff from enas 194
Really cool course. Lots of material from both EE and MechE. Learnt things from CPUs to how motors work and made our own suntracking device.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths are that the lectures were very informative, and the labs really helped us confirm what we had learned in lecture. The weaknesses are that a lot of previous knowledge is needed, and sometimes things were not fully explained in class.

This was an excellent course overall, perhaps one thing that could be implemented would be more practice for the homework using things such as Matlab. We practiced often in Arduino during the labs but we had one homework assignment in Matlab and I feel as if we did not fully go over the useful techniques of Matlab coding.

The lectures were really great, but the labs were a little too simple. That's not to say that the labs were easy, but it would have been nice if we had actually had labs on control systems instead of on other random stuff.
I can only say good things about this course, I genuinely was interested in the topic, and that is mainly thanks to our Prof. Madhu and our amazing TAs Khoi and Ali

This class had a heavier workload than most other engineering classes, but the professor and TAs made sure that the work was still manageable. I enjoyed how the labs were extremely helpful in helping us prepare for the final project.

Both the lab and lecture are interesting, but it's hard to keep up with the lecture material due to the lack of regular problem sets. I'd be weary of increasing the workload of the class, but it did seem to be an issue
Good labs, but the theoretical stuff in class was sometimes hard to connect to real applications.

This course does a very good job at teaching towards the final project, which is to build a system that can track a light source. Therefore, while the labs aim to teach general concepts, such as programming in assembly code, building circuits, and operating the Arduino system, it does so through the lens of the final project. While this does make the final project easier and offer greater potential to exceed expectations, it does limit the overall possibilities of the labs themselves. The lecture does not follow the same approach, and is therefore more general. However, this could lead to concepts being covered in lecture that are never touched in practice, thus leaving for holes in practical knowledge.
Some lectures are really boring and unnecessary while others are fantastic. Otherwise, this course is extremely well organized, taught, and helped by some truly amazing and patient TA's.

I thought this was a great course, though I wish there was more time to better understand the topics. In the latter portion of the semester, some of the circuit theory was difficult to comprehend, especially because it was so abstract. I did appreciate however that the professor tried to highlight the significance of why we were delving into a complicated derivation. I also wished we had more time to work on the final project as it seemed like a quick turnaround from the last lab, especially considering the project was to be completed at the beginning of Reading Week.

The class is very interesting, but is largely focused on a lab attached. The coursework in class and the lab work are largely separated, and dont have too much to do with one another except in optional ways. Furthermore, the overall grading was very ambiguous. There were tons of extra credit stuff but the class was curved as a whole so it wasnt really optional. People ended the class with a 95 and had a B+, but there was no indication that this would be the case until it was done. Seems pretty absurd and unfair
I thought the course was very well balanced, the pace was pretty consistent, the lectures were mostly useful, and the quizzes were very fair

Very organized. very good notes, very helpful TAs. Labs that actually teach us something and we can actually apply the knowledge to the final project. Our feedback actually mattered in this class. This is my favorite course and I am not even MechE ( I am an EE major).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If Madhu is teaching and you are taking the class because it's required, not because you care, you probably don't need to go to class except for the day before each quiz and the quiz days themselves. Read up before lab and you'll be fine. There was a strong disconnect between lab work and class work.

Fully recommend.
The more work you put in, the more you get out of the course.
Madhu is a gem
Yes, I think every engineer should take this course. While a MENG course, the topics we learn are applicable to EE, CS, and even biomedical engineering based on what the final project is.

I would recommend this class to another student because we literally got to build a robot that simulated tracking the sun. It was one of the coolest things I've done at Yale. The only draw back is that this class is both a lab and lecture (and only 1 credit) so it can be very time consuming.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who is interested in control systems. This course provides a nice introduction to many fundamental topics in control technology, and is really fun as well!
For sure. For both Electricla engineering and mechanical students alike!
I would recommend this course to any engineering major who wants to learn the basics of circuit design and implementation.
I think the class needs to be reworked a little bit. Particularly because it's difficult to keep up with the lecture material. It has a lot of potential though

If you are taking this course for the Mechanical Engineering degree, I would absolutely recommend it. It is a great way to integrate practice of mechanical engineering theory with practical implementation, especially with more advanced work like building circuits and systems, and programming new devices. Overall, I think that if you want to get more engineering experience, this is a class that can do that well.
Yes! My favorite class at Yale and I'm not even a MechE major.
I would absolutely recommend this course to any engineer at yale. I'ts been one of my favorite courses I've ever taken and I wish I could take it again.
This is the class that lets you put together your knowledge of dynamics, electronics, and programming to build a cool device. Would definitely recommend if you like making things!
Not unless you have to do it. The grading was ridiculous

If you're taking it, it's because you have to. But with that being said, it's a pretty good class, way better than everyone said it would be. Definitely a lot of work, so pony up. But super rewarding when you plug in that final project and everything works. Also, have a lab partner. I didn't have one and it made my life a living hell.

PLEASE TAKE THIS COURSE IF YOU ARE EE OR MECHE. Loved it, so organized, learn so much, actually cool final projects and labs, and a professor that actually cares for his students and appreciates feedback. Couldn't have asked for a better course
